data.title: Editor Freeze constantly
data.body:
This is really frustrating when i open Editor and freeze it there until the system prompt me to say keep waiting or close it down. 

I google it out, there is only one way that work for me which is delete the folder c://users/users/.atom/storage then open the editor.

although, it works but it still not a long term solution, whenever my editor is freezing and i delete that folder. Also, my recently files open and project is gonna so i need to re-add my project folder.

Please Advice if have any better solution. I hope this issue will rectify soon!

I using Window 10, 32-bit, my editor version 1.12.6

data.title: Question: How to close buffer without killing it?
data.body: I am used to Emacs where I can close a buffer but not kill it (meaning it is still in memory). This is useful for example when I'm running a REPL in a buffer. I would like to close/hide the buffer and quickly open it back up when I need to. How can this be done?

data.title: Overriding nonWordCharacters is unwieldy
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

(Some pre-reqs have been omitted because they don't apply)

### Description

Paraphrasing from my comment over at https://github.com/atom/bracket-matcher/pull/249#issuecomment-264072613...

There's no way to respect the user's setting when overriding `nonWordCharacters` in a scope-specific setting since `nonWordCharacters` is a single string.  That means it's an all-or-nothing change, rather than being able to add or remove characters as necessary.

For example, $ is a valid identifier for many languages. However the default `nonWordCharacters` includes `$`, which means attempting to double-click to select a variable with `$` in it will only select part of it. The best way to fix this currently is to override `nonWordCharacters` in the language settings by copying/pasting the default value and removing the `$`. However, this totally disregards any customizations the user may have made.

**Possible solutions**:
* The best one I could think of is adding some type of new setting that takes scenarios like these into account.

### Steps to Reproduce

N/A - this is an API limitation.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.14.0-dev-d3d06fb
Electron: 1.4.7
Chrome  : 53.0.2785.143
Node    : 6.5.0
```
on Windows 10 x64.

/cc @nathansobo

data.title: Remembering Removed Project Folder(s)
data.body:
### Description
Discovered on a Mac!

User view: If you remove a project folder from atom, the next time you close and reopen Atom the project returns.  

Under the hood: You can see what's going on in the ~/.atom/storage/application.json file. When you remove a project, the initial path is not removed from the file. So on reboot it comes back as if it were never removed at all. 

### Steps to Reproduce (for mac)

1. Right Click Project -> Remove Project Folder
2. Command-Q to quit atom
3. Reboot to find the return of the project.

**Expected behavior:** 
I would expect that when you remove a project folder that it stays removed and does not come back on a separate session. Projects that are added should be added and those that are removed should be removed. 

**Actual behavior:** 
The removed projects persist between sessions. It seems that 'Remove Project Folder' just graphically removes it. 

### Versions

Atom    : 1.12.6
Electron: 1.3.9
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Running On Mac 
OS X El Capitan Version 10.11.6

data.title: Proper usage of script/build for a user-level install?
data.body:
Building from source was not a problem for me up to (and including) **v1.10.2**.

Since then I have been met with multiple problems and errors while trying to build. Today I attempted to build **v1.12.6** and received an error identical to #12549.

Reading through the documentation it seems the workflow is to install at the system level. This doesn't work for me as I always install to "$HOME/.local" so that I replicate my build on servers where I don't have admin (root) access.

Previously I would do the following.

1. `./script/build`
2. `./script/test`
3. `./script/grunt install --install-dir "$HOME/.local"`

Every version since v1.10.2 (v1.11.* and v1.12.*) have failed to build on my system (step 1). I am unsure how to continue since the documentation only includes directions for a system-level install.

data.title: Invalid syntax coloring for Python code containing SQL-like string literals
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.

### Description

Syntax coloring do not work correctly for Python code that follows a string literal with a certain content.

After the literal the code is colored as string, as if the literal did not end.

I tried a few variants to pin down the bug, and the conditions seem to be at least:
1) The literal is a triple-quoted string, using double quotes. It does not matter if it spans a single line or multiple lines.
2) The literal contains an SQL keyword in single quotes.
3) The keyword is uppercase.
4) Not all SQL keywords trigger the bug. SELECT and UPDATE do, INSERT do not.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a new tab, switch language to Python
2. Enter following code:
```python
"""'SELECT'"""
pass
```

**Expected behavior:**

Second line should be colored as code.

**Actual behavior:**

Second line is colored as part of string literal.

### Versions

OS: Linux Mint 18

Atom:
Atom    : 1.12.6
Electron: 1.3.9
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

APM:
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.11.0

data.title: Replace `libXScrnSaver` with `libXss.so.1` in RPM package spec
Modified keymap 'ctrl-q' to save files before quiting
data.body:
This discussion (https://discuss.atom.io/t/quit-confirmation/5572) and the issue #6082 discusses how useful would be having a warning message before quitting because, sometimes when multiple buffers and multiple windows are opened, user wants to close current buffer in current window by pressing Ctrl+W. Unfortunately, they inadvertently pressed Ctrl+Q and everything disappears. If it's a completely new file on a new window, all the written code is lost.
Atom's community manager opposed this warning message, he said:
>I philosophically disagree with quit confirmations because I believe that quit confirmations are solving a real problem with red tape. The real problem is "I don't want to lose data accidentally".

So I decide a different approach, changing the keymap 'ctrl-q', to first save all documents and only after it would quit the program.

Hope you find this useful and that I'm using the proper channel.

data.title: On need (dynamic) plugin loading
data.body:
## Rationale

Atom is a great multipurpose text editor, and the one that best suit my need. But depending on the usage, it may become too much multipurpose as adding more and more plugins to support many usages quickly makes it a bloatware.

For a concrete example, I'm using Atom as a text editor, a markdown editor, a C/C++ IDE, and sometimes as a C# IDE or a Python IDE. I end up with lots of specific usage plugins which increase startup time and resource usage for nothing: clang-autocomplete and clang-linter are useless in C#, and OmniSharp is useless in C/C++, even worst, both are not needed when I want to quickly edit a text file, and waiting several seconds to edit a text file is quite boring.

There are some workarounds, like enabling plugins per project, but loading plugins only when needed would be easier, more flexible and sometimes the only alternative (when using Atom as a simple text editor with language plugins for example).

## Typical usages

* IDE / advanced text editor: This is mostly the typical usage. It uses plugins providing autocompletion, linting and some other language-specific features (markdown-preview for example). It also uses CVS, but not always.
* Simple text editor: I know that there are editors more suited for this, but why having multiple text editors for multiple usages when we have a modular one? And, why not, maybe a fool in the future will even make an office suite plugin to replace LibreOffice...

## Some brainstorming

Plugins would be separated in two types :
* always-enabled plugins, which are (almost?) always usefull / wanted like the project-manager plugin. These would be always loaded on start.
* usage-specific plugins, which are usefull only on some condition, like language linters. These would be loaded only when the conditions are met.
* dependency-only plugin, which are useless on themselves, like the linter plugin. These would be loaded only when another plugin need them.

To let plugin writers handle this change slightly, plugins not reporting their type would be considered as always-enabled plugins.

Conditions would include, but not be extaustive to :
* the open file(s) / project(s) language(s) : Some plugins would be explicitely related to some language(s). For quick opening of Atom, language plugins would be loaded on file open. To avoid often loads and unloads, a plugin would be unloaded only when there is no file of this language in the project anymore.
* the presence of a file / directory in the project : Obviously, I don't need git-status if I have no `.git` folder in my project. The same goes for the build plugin with the .atom-build file.

As some plugins need some dependencies but may not always report them correctly (especially for those which depend on default plugins), I suggest a "force always-loaded" setting to let time to reflect the change to plugin writers.

## The word of the end

I'm not an Atom developper, and I know that this is a very big work and that it likely needs code refactoring. The behavior like the implementation details need to be carefully thought to avoid making plugin management a big mess. I don't expect to see it anytime soon, but it would make Atom the perfect text editor / IDE (at least for me).

data.title: Custom build with modified atom.sh doesn't work?
data.body:
I tried doing a custom build by cloning and then modifying atom.sh, changing the application name to "Atom2.app" and the settings folder to ".atom2", but none of the atom.sh settings persisted. It was still created as "Atom.app" and the settings folder remained ".atom".

Can anybody point me in the right direction?

The main reason for doing this is to have multiple separate instances of Atom running on one machine, all using different setting folders and being recognized as different apps from the OS.

Thanks very much.

data.body:
When I try to install the rpm there is one dependency that it isn't possible to resolve: 
libXScrnSaver
I tried to install and added the repository 
http://download.opensuse.org/repositories/X11:/XOrg/openSUSE_Tumbleweed/
but that library with that name doesn't exit. In addition, I have installed theses libraries
libXss1 and libXss-devel but it continues ask me for the libXScrnSaver library
Anyway I tried to install from sources with 
sudo script/build --install
everything seems that works fine but when I try to execute it, the process is executing but the editor doesn't show.

data.title: Reopen window invisible (on disconnected monitor) on Windows 7 virtual machine with VMWare Fusion
data.body:
### Description
Atom editor window is invisible if it closed on 2nd monitor previously and 2nd monitor is disconnected. I'm running on Windows 7 VM on MAC with Fusion 7 unity mode.

### Steps to Reproduce
I run a Windows 7 VM on MAC with VMWare Fusion 7. The VM is in unity mode. 

1. Open Atom editor on 2nd monitor and close it.
2. Suspend VM
3. Disconnect 2nd monitor
4. Resume VM
5. Open Atom editor

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
The Atom window should show on my primary monitor since 2nd monitor is disconnected

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
The Atom window is not visible. It is actually opened on the disconnected monitor. I have to change VM view from unity to single window, right click the small atom window on bottom and choose move, then use keyboard and mouse to bring the window to my primary monitor.

### Versions
<= 1.12.6

data.title: Replace `space-pen` with `atom-select-list` in `ReopenProjectListView`
data.body: This pull request uses atom-select-list as a drop-in replacement for atom-space-pen-views. Feature-wise nothing should change, but this will help remove jQuery from Atom.

data.title: Editor freezes when saving a file for the first time on launch
data.body:
When I open up Atom, and then when I make changes to a file, the first time I save the changes using `Ctrl + S`, the editor freezes for approx. 8 seconds. If I make another change and then save it again, it doesn't freeze. This happened on version 1.11 too and it still present today. I firstly thought that it  was a problem with my system, but even with the fresh installment of the OS, the issue is still present. It happened on "Windows 10" and it is present on "Windows 7" also. So here is the reproduction of the issue.

Atom version: **1.12.6**
- Open up Atom.
- Make changes to a file for the first time, press `Ctrl + S`, editor freezes for approx. 8 seconds.
- Make another change to the exact same file, press `Ctrl + S` again, editor doesn't freeze.

Now, it might also be a problem with one of the packages, but I'm not sure though. Here is the list of packages that I use.

- Atom Beautify ( https://atom.io/packages/atom-beautify )
- Monokai Theme ( https://atom.io/themes/monokai )
- File Icons ( https://atom.io/packages/file-icons )

data.title: Activate packages immediately if hook had already been triggered
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/13200#issuecomment-264423190

This pull request fixes a subtle bug that prevented hooks from being triggered on packages that were activated *after* Atom's initialization. In particular, when installing or disabling/enabling a package that relied on the `core:loaded-shell-environment` hook, such package would never activate because the hook had already been triggered.

This problem was not specific to `core:loaded-shell-environment`: in facts, the `grammar-used` hook was affected by it as well, although it was less evident because a `grammar-used` hook is emitted every time a new file is opened, rather than just once as it happens for `core:loaded-shell-environment`.

With this pull request, when a package is activated (either after installing it or after re-enabling it) we will re-trigger all the activation hooks that have been triggered until that moment. In addition, after a package has been successfully activated, we will stop listening to further activation (hooks and commands) events for that specific package.

/cc: @atom/maintainers @joefitzgerald

data.title: Active tab not showing in tabs
data.body: When there is too many tabs in atom. Current active tab is not highlighted . In sublime there is one icon to scroll in tabs. But atom does not have icon or not automatically highlighting the active tab.

data.title: Toggle line comment prints "undefined" when language unknown
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

__Proposed Solution:__ #847 

In a new file (untitled and unsaved) or in a file with an unrecognized file extensions, pressing the <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>/</kbd> shortcut to toggle the line comments (comment the line out) it prints out in the editor `undefined`. I am very confident this arises from the editor returning `undefined` because it cannot determine a comment identifier for an unknown language.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom (with or without safe mode)
2. Press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>N</kbd> to open a new file
3. Press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>/</kbd> to toggle line comment

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

I expected Atom to either ignore the command, or to issue a warning.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

The editor instead printed `undefined`

### Versions

#### Application
Atom    : 1.12.6
Electron: 1.3.9
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

#### Community Packages
* atom-clock
* autocomplete-python
* file-icons
* merge-conflicts
* wakatime

#### System Information

**OS:** Microsoft Windows 10 Home
**OS Version:** 10.0.14393 Build 14393
**Device:** Dell Inspiron 7559 x64 PC

data.title: project find results not allowing display of more than one match
data.body:
### Description

When using the `project find results` UI (via ctrl+shift+f for me), when searching for things that occur in multiple files, all attempts to open the next occurrence the tab for the prior occurrence.  

### Steps to Reproduce

1.  Use ctrl + shift + f to search for something string you know to exist in multiple places within the project
2. click on the first occurrence
3. go back to the project find results tab and click another occurrence in a separate file

**Expected behavior:** I expect to see three tabs, a tab housing `project find results`, a tab containing the file of the first match to my search, and a third tab containing the second match to my search.

**Actual behavior:**  I only see two tabs, a tab housing `project find results`, and a tab containing the second match to my search.  

### Versions
```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.6
Electron: 1.3.9
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

data.title: Terminal window not closing when program terminates
data.body:
### Description

After the program terminates and I'm prompted to 

> press any key to continue...

I get no results and the compiler shows me

> 27:35: execution error: Atom Helper got an error: Application isn’t running. (-600)
logout
Saving session...
...copying shared history...
...saving history...truncating history files...
...completed.
Deleting expired sessions...507 completed.

[Process completed]

### Steps to Reproduce

1. press command+F7 to build and run the code
2. the programs runs
3. the program terminates and the user is prompt to press a key to go back to Atom editor

**Expected behavior:** The first times I used Atom the terminal used to be close with success.

**Actual behavior:** Now the terminal is not closed automatically after the program terminated and I press any key to continue.

### My Atom version:
Atom    : 1.12.6
Electron: 1.3.9
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

data.title: Specs: test reliability & auto temp clean-up
data.body:
This started-off as trying to figure out why a few tests fail under Windows and indeed should fix a couple of them.

In doing so I decided to make the tests clean up after themselves so that;

- I could see what was going on
- Any resource leaks/locks would show up (there is at least 1 in libgit2/git-utils)
- I didn't have to keep deleting %TEMP% (not automatic on Windows)
- I could now run the specs against a small RAM disk instead (down from 4 minutes to 2)
